Quadratic equations

1. Revision of completing the square & quadratic formula

Completing the square: when a≠1a≠1

  1. Suppose we start with the expression shown here:

    3p2+2p3p2+2p

    If we want to complete the square for this expression, we must add the correct number. We also must subtract that same number so that the overall value of the expression does not change. If NN represents the correct number to add and subtract, we are looking for something like this:

    3p2+2p+N−N3p2+2p+N−N

    Determine the value of NN, which will complete the square. Your answer must be exact (not rounded).

    Answer: The number to complete the square is .
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    The quadratic coefficient of 33 is quite a nuisance in this question. The only way to get it out of the way is to factorise it out of the original expression.

    STEP: Factorise out the quadratic coefficient, 33
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    If we must complete the square for an expression and the quadratic coefficient is not 11, we need to change the expression so that the quadratic coefficient is "out of the way." That means we must factorise the quadratic coefficient out of the expression. This may bring fractions into the expression, but there is no other way!

    3p2+2p+N−N=3(p2+2p3+N3−N3)3p2+2p+N−N=3(p2+2p3+N3−N3)

    Now complete the square inside the brackets by using the value (b2)2(b2)2. It is always a good idea when completing the square to calculate the value of b2b2, which you will probably use later. b2=12b=12(23)=13b2=12b=12(23)=13. Then, the number we must add (and subtract) inside the brackets to complete the square is:

    (b2)2=(13)2=19(b2)2=(13)2=19

    Therefore, we must add 1919 to the expression.

    STEP: Determine the value of NN
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We need to compare the value we calculated above to the value of NN. We found above that we need to add (and subtract) 1919 to the expression p2+2p3p2+2p3, which is the expression inside of the brackets. So:

    33(p2+2p3+N3−N3)must become:(p2+2p3+19−19)3(p2+2p3+N3−N3)must become:3(p2+2p3+19−19)

    So that means:

    N3NN=19=3(19)=13N3=19N=3(19)N=13
    NOTE:

    You can see that the number we get is actually 3(19)3(19). This is the number we must add (and subtract) to the original expression. The factor of 33 comes from the quadratic coefficient, which we factorised out. But it is still part of the expression. The original expression, with the value of NN included, is:

    3p2+2p+13−133p2+2p+13−13

    The final answer is: N=13N=13.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Now factorise the completed expression from above so that it contains a squared binomial. For example, it might look like: 2(x−259)2−142(x−259)2−14.

    Answer: The expression will be: .
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    You need to factorise the expression 3(p2+2p3+19−19)3(p2+2p3+19−19) so that it has the arrangement 3(p±?)2−?3(p±?)2−?.

    STEP: Use the result from Question 1 to get the answer
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The first thing we need to do is separate out the last term from the other terms. We do this because we can only factorise the other terms (the last term is only there as an echo from our work to complete the square on the first two terms).

    3=3(p2+2p3+19−19)(p2+2p3+19)−133(p2+2p3+19−19)=3(p2+2p3+19)−13

    Now we can factorise the trinomial in the brackets:

    3=3=3(p2+2p3+19)−13(p+13)(p+13)−13(p+13)2−133(p2+2p3+19)−13=3(p+13)(p+13)−13=3(p+13)2−13

    The correct answer is 3(p+13)2−133(p+13)2−13.

The quadratic formula: solving quadratic equations

Find the value(s) of nn which solve the following equation. Use the quadratic formula.

n2−4n+4=0n2−4n+4=0
NOTE: While it may be possible to solve this equation by factorisation, the question says that you should solve the equation using the quadratic formula; you will only earn full marks on a test or exam if you solve it using the formula.
INSTRUCTIONS:
  • Round irrational answers to two decimal places.
  • If the answer is non-real, type non-real in the answer box.
  • If there are two answers, separate the answer with a semi-colon.
    For example: 1,23 ; 4,56. The order of the answers does not matter.
Answer: n=n=
one-of
type(list.type(numeric.noerror).unordered)
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

First make sure that the equation is in standard form. Then find the values of aa, bb and cc. Substitute them into the quadratic formula and go for it!

STEP: Determine the values of a,ba,b and cc
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

This equation is already in standard form, so we can read the values of aa, bb and cc directly from the equation:

n2−4n+4=0n2−4n+4=0
a=1,b=−4,c=4a=1,b=−4,c=4
STEP: Use the quadratic formula
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Now write down the formula, and substitute in the values for aa, bb and cc. Remember to substitute with brackets, which helps with the negative signs!

n=−b±b2−4ac‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2a=−(−4)±(−4)2−4(1)(4)‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2(1)=4±16−16‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2=4±0‾√2n=−b±b2−4ac2a=−(−4)±(−4)2−4(1)(4)2(1)=4±16−162=4±02

In this case, the radicand (the number in the square root) is zero. That means there will only be one answer.

n=4±02=42=2n=4±02=42=2

The final answer is n=2n=2.

Submit your answer as:

The quadratic formula: managing equations first

Use the quadratic formula to solve the equation shown.

−z23−4z3−43=0−z23−4z3−43=0
INSTRUCTIONS:
  • List your answers separated by a semi-colon ; .
  • Give your answer(s) as a decimal rounded to two places if appropriate.
  • If the answer(s) are not real numbers, type non-real.
Answer: z=z=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

The equation is in standard form, but there is something you should do to help yourself make the question simpler before you use the quadratic formula.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

Before starting to solve the equation, it is a good idea to multiply the entire equation by −3−3 because of the fractions in the equation: cancel the denominators before you substitute into the quadratic formula. (This is not a necessary step, but there are numerous reasons why it is helpful in lots of cases!)

(−3)−z23−4z3−43=0(−z23−4z3−43)=(0)(−3)z2+4z+4=0−z23−4z3−43=0(−3)(−z23−4z3−43)=(0)(−3)z2+4z+4=0
STEP: <no title>
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

You have the value for a, b and c sitting in the equation now, so write down the formula and go for it. Remember to substitute with brackets, which helps with the negative signs!

→za=1,b=4,c=4=−b±b2−4ac‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2a=−(4)±(4)2−4(1)(4)‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2(1)=−4±16−16‾‾‾‾‾‾‾√2=−4±0‾√2→a=1,b=4,c=4z=−b±b2−4ac2a=−(4)±(4)2−4(1)(4)2(1)=−4±16−162=−4±02

In this case, the radicand (the number in the square root) is zero. That means there will only be one answer.

z=−4±02=−42=−2z=−4±02=−42=−2

The final answer is z=−2z=−2.

Completing the square

  1. For the expression shown here, determine what value (what number) will complete the square.

    a2−4a+?a2−4a+?
    Answer:

    The number to complete the square is .

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to use the linear coefficient, −4−4, to find the answer. To complete the square, you must add (b2)2(b2)2 to the expression, where bb is the linear coefficient.

    STEP: Use the linear coefficient to figure out the number which will complete the square
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To complete the square, we need to add a number to the expression so that it will fit the squared binomial pattern

    (m+n)2=m2+2mn+n2(m+n)2=m2+2mn+n2

    If bb is the linear coefficient, then we must add the value (b2)2(b2)2 to complete the square. In the expression above, bb is equal to −4−4. Start with the value

    b2=(−4)2=−2b2=(−4)2=−2

    This value is almost always important when you complete the square. Then, the number we must add to complete the square is:

    (b2)2=(−2)2=4(b2)2=(−2)2=4

    When we complete the square, the expression becomes a2−4a+4a2−4a+4 (you will use this in the next question).

    The number we need to complete the square is 44.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. Now factorise the completed expression from above so that it is a squared binomial. For example, the answer might look like (x−3)2(x−3)2.

    Answer: The expression will be: .
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to factorise the expression a2−4a+4a2−4a+4 so that it has the arrangement (a±?)2(a±?)2.

    STEP: Use the answer from Question 1 to write down the answer
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In the first part of the problem, we found that b2=−2b2=−2; this is the value which sits in the binomial when we factorise:

    a2−4a+4=(a−2)(a−2)=(a−2)2a2−4a+4=(a−2)(a−2)=(a−2)2

    It is clear now why the value for completing the square will be the square of 22: when we multiply the brackets (with FOIL) one of the terms we get will be 22 multiplied by itself - that is why completing the square uses the number (b2)2(b2)2.

    The correct answer is (a−2)2(a−2)2.

    Submit your answer as:

Exercises

Completing the square: when a≠1a≠1

  1. Suppose we start with the expression shown here:

    2d2+2d2d2+2d

    If we want to complete the square for this expression, we must add the correct number. We also must subtract that same number so that the overall value of the expression does not change. If NN represents the correct number to add and subtract, we are looking for something like this:

    2d2+2d+N−N2d2+2d+N−N

    Determine the value of NN, which will complete the square. Your answer must be exact (not rounded).

    Answer: The number to complete the square is .
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    The quadratic coefficient of 22 is quite a nuisance in this question. The only way to get it out of the way is to factorise it out of the original expression.

    STEP: Factorise out the quadratic coefficient, 22
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    If we must complete the square for an expression and the quadratic coefficient is not 11, we need to change the expression so that the quadratic coefficient is "out of the way." That means we must factorise the quadratic coefficient out of the expression. This may bring fractions into the expression, but there is no other way!

    2d2+2d+N−N=2(d2+d+N2−N2)2d2+2d+N−N=2(d2+d+N2−N2)

    Now complete the square inside the brackets by using the value (b2)2(b2)2. It is always a good idea when completing the square to calculate the value of b2b2, which you will probably use later. b2=12b=12(1)=12b2=12b=12(1)=12. Then, the number we must add (and subtract) inside the brackets to complete the square is:

    (b2)2=(12)2=14(b2)2=(12)2=14

    Therefore, we must add 1414 to the expression.

    STEP: Determine the value of NN
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We need to compare the value we calculated above to the value of NN. We found above that we need to add (and subtract) 1414 to the expression d2+dd2+d, which is the expression inside of the brackets. So:

    22(d2+d+N2−N2)must become:(d2+d+14−14)2(d2+d+N2−N2)must become:2(d2+d+14−14)

    So that means:

    N2NN=14=2(14)=12N2=14N=2(14)N=12
    NOTE:

    You can see that the number we get is actually 2(14)2(14). This is the number we must add (and subtract) to the original expression. The factor of 22 comes from the quadratic coefficient, which we factorised out. But it is still part of the expression. The original expression, with the value of NN included, is:

    2d2+2d+12−122d2+2d+12−12

    The final answer is: N=12N=12.

Find the value(s) of zz which solve the following equation. Use the quadratic formula.

4z2−z+3=04z2−z+3=0

Completing the square

  1. For the expression shown here, determine what value (what number) will complete the square.

    x2−8x+?x2−8x+?
    Answer:

    The number to complete the square is .

    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to use the linear coefficient, −8−8, to find the answer. To complete the square, you must add (b2)2(b2)2 to the expression, where bb is the linear coefficient.

    STEP: Use the linear coefficient to figure out the number which will complete the square
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    To complete the square, we need to add a number to the expression so that it will fit the squared binomial pattern

    (m+n)2=m2+2mn+n2(m+n)2=m2+2mn+n2

    If bb is the linear coefficient, then we must add the value (b2)2(b2)2 to complete the square. In the expression above, bb is equal to −8−8. Start with the value

    b2=(−8)2=−4b2=(−8)2=−4

    This value is almost always important when you complete the square. Then, the number we must add to complete the square is:

    (b2)2=(−4)2=16(b2)2=(−4)2=16

    When we complete the square, the expression becomes x2−8x+16x2−8x+16 (you will use this in the next question).

    The number we need to complete the square is 1616.

  2. Now factorise the completed expression from above so that it is a squared binomial. For example, the answer might look like (x−3)2(x−3)2.

    Answer: The expression will be: .
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    You need to factorise the expression x2−8x+16x2−8x+16 so that it has the arrangement (x±?)2(x±?)2.

    STEP: Use the answer from Question 1 to write down the answer
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    In the first part of the problem, we found that b2=−4b2=−4; this is the value which sits in the binomial when we factorise:

    x2−8x+16=(x−4)(x−4)=(x−4)2x2−8x+16=(x−4)(x−4)=(x−4)2

    It is clear now why the value for completing the square will be the square of 44: when we multiply the brackets (with FOIL) one of the terms we get will be 44 multiplied by itself - that is why completing the square uses the number (b2)2(b2)2.

    The correct answer is (x−4)2(x−4)2.

2. Sum & product of roots

Simultaneous equations

Solve the following equations simultaneously:

−2yx=2−5x=y+1−2y=2−5xx=y+1
Answer: x=x= and y=y= .
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

The first thing you need to do is substitute x=y+1x=y+1 into the first equation.

STEP: Combine the equations using substitution
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

We must solve the two equations 'simultaneously'. This means we want one pair of xx and yy values which solves both equations.

There are two methods for solving equations simultaneously: elimination and substitution. For the equations in this question, substitution is the better choice. This is because the second equation already shows us that xx is equal to x=y+1x=y+1, which is exactly what we need for the substitution method. (We could solve these equations using the elimination method, but it will require more work.)

So we can substitute y+1y+1 into the first equation in place of xx:

−2yx−2y=2−5x=y+1=2−5(y+1)−2y=2−5xx=y+1−2y=2−5(y+1)
NOTE: We could substitute the other variable if we want to; but the substitution above is the best choice because the xx in the second equation is already the subject of the equation.
STEP: Solve for yy
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 4 points left]

Now that there is only one variable in the equation, we can solve the equation. Distribute the −5−5 and get on with solving the equation.

−2y−2y−2y5y−2y3yy=2−5(y+1)=2−5(y)−5(1)=2−5y−5=2−5=−3=−1−2y=2−5(y+1)−2y=2−5(y)−5(1)−2y=2−5y−55y−2y=2−53y=−3y=−1
STEP: Solve for xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

So y=−1y=−1. But remember that we also need an answer for xx. It is important to remember that you can use either equation to calculate xx, because the numbers we want solve both equations. It is good to pick the easiest choice. In this case, the easiest choice is the second equation, because it is arranged in a more useful way.

xxxx=y+1=(−1)+1=−1+1=0x=y+1x=(−1)+1x=−1+1x=0

The numbers which solve the equations simultaneously are x=0x=0 and y=−1y=−1. We can see this represented beautifully if we graph the two equations: the answers we just found are the coordinates of the point where the lines intersect.

The values which solve these two equations are x=0x=0 and y=−1y=−1.

It is good to pick the easiest choice. In this case, the easiest choice is the first equation, because it is arranged in a more useful way.

xxxx=5y+5=5(−2)+5=−10+5=−5x=5y+5x=5(−2)+5x=−10+5x=−5

The numbers which solve the equations simultaneously are x=−5x=−5 and y=−2y=−2. We can see this represented beautifully if we graph the two equations: the answers we just found are the coordinates of the point where the lines intersect.

The values which solve these two equations are x=−5x=−5 and y=−2y=−2.

Simultaneous equations

Solve the following equations simultaneously:

x3y=−4y+4=−20+5xx=−4y+43y=−20+5x
Answer: x=x= and y=y= .
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

The first thing you need to do is substitute x=−4y+4x=−4y+4 into the second equation.

STEP: Combine the equations using substitution
[−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

We must solve the two equations 'simultaneously'. This means we want one pair of xx and yy values which solves both equations.

There are two methods for solving equations simultaneously: elimination and substitution. For the equations in this question, substitution is the better choice. This is because the first equation already shows us that xx is equal to x=−4y+4x=−4y+4, which is exactly what we need for the substitution method. (We could solve these equations using the elimination method, but it will require more work.)

So we can substitute −4y+4−4y+4 into the second equation in place of xx:

3yx3y=−20+5x=−4y+4=−20+5(−4y+4)3y=−20+5xx=−4y+43y=−20+5(−4y+4)
NOTE: We could substitute the other variable if we want to; but the substitution above is the best choice because the xx in the first equation is already the subject of the equation.
STEP: Solve for yy
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 4 points left]

Now that there is only one variable in the equation, we can solve the equation. Distribute the 55 and get on with solving the equation.

3y3y3y20y+3y23yy=−20+5(−4y+4)=−20+5(−4y)+5(4)=−20−20y+20=−20+20=0=03y=−20+5(−4y+4)3y=−20+5(−4y)+5(4)3y=−20−20y+2020y+3y=−20+2023y=0y=0
STEP: Solve for xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

So y=0y=0. But remember that we also need an answer for xx. It is important to remember that you can use either equation to calculate xx, because the numbers we want solve both equations. It is good to pick the easiest choice. In this case, the easiest choice is the first equation, because it is arranged in a more useful way.

xxxx=−4y+4=−4(0)+4=0+4=4x=−4y+4x=−4(0)+4x=0+4x=4

The numbers which solve the equations simultaneously are x=4x=4 and y=0y=0. We can see this represented beautifully if we graph the two equations: the answers we just found are the coordinates of the point where the lines intersect.

The values which solve these two equations are x=4x=4 and y=0y=0.
